column2: If you would seek victory, first align with justice

This is our last release before the really big one -- next up, we'll be launching the full Archipelago market. It's going to be üî•, can't wait to show you all what a truly collector-centric NFT marketplace will feel like. 

Until then--happy browsing and happy collecting!

Speaking as a collector myself, I'm confident that exploring the market using Archipelago, and then going to OpenSea to make the purchase, is the best way to collect generative art. I used our beta branch to pick up some Chimeras and it was üßëüèΩ‚Äçüç≥üòò

But, building a great collection means finding grail pieces no-matter where they're listed. And OpenSea orderbook has some true gems... they can just be a bit hard to find sometimes ü§£. So we're super pleased that Archipelago can make collector's lives a bit easier.

Archipelago's mission is to create the best possible experience for collecting generative art. That's why we're building a tailored marketplace with trait bidding, lower fees (just 1%), and a super smooth UX.

Dear @artblocks_io collectors: the @archipelago_art team has a bear market surprise for you! We've integrated @opensea pricing data for all ArtBlocks pieces into Archipelago. Check it out here: https://t.co/5Nhj92TdVk

I'm super interested in NFT-powered social experiences, which means I'm super interested in @prtyDAO making group NFT purchases easy. 

So, I decided to give it a spin on one of my favorite projects: Meridians by @mattdesl. We're going for Meridian 837: 
https://t.co/MbcwMgYRU1

If you'd like to be a part of our earliest beta cohort, please add your email address to the beta signup list here: https://t.co/CIs4Rz3Ejr

Can't wait to have you all onboard for the launch üòò

As for timelines: the art explorer is already live. We're going to ship the OpenSea data integration concurrently with writing the marketplace backend, so you can expect that in December. We'll actually launch the marketplace in January.

It's with this question in mind that I share the most exciting new update: Archipelago will have a token! We want to recognize and reward the early adopters we depend on. So we'll be distributing the token liberally to early users ‚ò∫Ô∏è
The key question for Archipelago is whether people are willing to migrate liquidity to a new marketplace. We can build it; but will you come?
That said, our marketplace will support some powerful new features from day 1. Most notably, we'll have collection-wide floor bids, a super smooth experience, and reduced fees (1% rather than 2.5%).

After that, we'll be launching the actual marketplace. We're going to deploy it cautiously and progressively, as keeping your NFTs safe is a top priority. The first beta launch will not request unlimited smart contract approvals, and it will only allow trading certain new drops.

Next up, we're going to integrate OpenSea marketplace data into the explorer. As a collector, knowing the floor prices and trade history is crucial to making informed decisions. Since we're building the site for collectors, we need to include all that info!

Our first step was launching the Archipelago Art Explorer. We put the art front-and-center, built in a trait explorer, and have optimized, buttery smooth performance. It's great on both mobile and desktop. Take it for a spin, and find some art you love!
https://t.co/qsGboBnov2
First, our focus: We are creating the best possible experience for discovering and collecting generative art NFTs. As collectors ourselves, we're making the marketplace that we wish already existed.

@elaifresh @liminal_warmth @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta I don't know the provenance of those projects you linked from @liminal_warmth's OpenSea, but I would bet money that both Cryptopunks and Ringers have made it into MoMA by the end of the decade.

Ringers, if you haven't seen them: https://t.co/HWKyELLWMZ

@elaifresh @liminal_warmth @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta Early impressionists were *trashed* by contemporary art critics. Reviews on Impression, Sunrise by Monet include: "Wallpaper in its embryonic state is more finished than this seascape!" https://t.co/O74ZxUf1IB

@liminal_warmth @waluigi_stan_1 @elaifresh @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta The same is true of the traditional art market (w diff participants). 

Whether or not you think enormous valuations on pieces by Monet are Picasso are "reasonable", they're definitely a stable part of our socioeconomic reality. The same will be true for significant NFT art.

@liminal_warmth @waluigi_stan_1 @elaifresh @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta The fact that generative art NFT valuations are so high (e.g. the Fidenza floor is 130E) reflects the existence of a confident crypto-native noveau riche, for whom these NFTs are status flexes, declarations of taste, and also investment pieces.

https://t.co/1nPUYKiqJD

@liminal_warmth @waluigi_stan_1 @elaifresh @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta However, generative art NFTs are the best example where the NFT *is* the art. The creation of the NFT specifically corresponds to the creation of the artwork, because the transaction minting the NFT supplies the random seed to the algorithm.

@liminal_warmth @waluigi_stan_1 @elaifresh @enkiv2 @mikerugnetta I'm not really the "owner" of MoM -- more, the owner of the crypto schelling point associated with MoM.

But, it has some real effects! There's a group that's planning to make a published version of the essay (hopefully w/ Scott's blessing) + I got added due to the NFT

@purphat @archipelago_art ü•∞

We got the team together last week, and hacking together has been a lot of fun. We've made solid progress. Some of it is almost ready to get shown off... but not quite yet üòâ

Stay tuned over the next 1-2 weeks. I'll have a demo to share, and an exciting announcement.

It amazes me every day that my go-to person on frontend design and my go-to person on the nuances of US securities law are the same person. 

Both of his skillsets will be vital for Archipelago, since we need a kickass frontend, and operate in a murky regulatory landscape.

The third co-founder is @ianjdarrow. Ian is one of the most capable designers and frontend developers that I've worked with. He's ALSO a lawyer and an expert on crypto regulatory policy; literally on the board at @BlockchainAssn. What. a. unicorn. üò±ü§©

Ever since, he's become my go-to resource on deep Solidity questions, and for smart contract security reviews. (He was the one who spotted that bundle attack I mentioned a few weeks ago.)

Having William on the team gives me a lot of confidence in our backend execution.

A few months ago, I persuaded William to leave his job at Google and learn Solidity. Many people would start with some tutorials. William's approach was to deep dive on the spec and semantics of the EVM, and then read through the full Uniswap code. This took him about 2 weeks üôÉ

First, there's @wchargin. He is an incredibly tasteful and talented software engineer. We first met when he was my intern at Google; still in college, and already a much stronger dev than me! ü§© We co-founded @sourcecred, so you could say we've got history.

After the rush of the initial Archipelago sprint, I realized that shipping a great product first requires building a great team. I'm happy to say that I'm co-founding Archipelago alongside two incredibly talented individuals. Allow me to tell you about them!

Hello all! It's been a little while since the last @archipelago_art update. I'd like to give updates on the team we've assembled, on our progress thus far, and on the roadmap. Today, to start, I'll brief on the team.

My favorite thing about this set is how the pieces seem to flow together, united by a band of white that bounces across the triptych. Taken together, I think of them as a river flowing from the highlands of abstraction and minimalism down to the marshes of complexity and chaos. https://t.co/Vns2s9ASAw

#467 closes the trio out, exploring Archetype's turbulent and chaotic side, and showcasing the vibrancy of the Paddle palette.

I missed this when it first came to market, and when I saw it in the Christie's set I thought I'd lost it. Luckily, I wound up getting a second chance! https://t.co/NLBXWLnFBh

I discovered @artblocks_io through falling in love with this project, and #36 was one of my first favorites. To me, it evokes a fantastically futuristic cityscape, or perhaps the surface of a computer chip. It finds harmony between regularity and complexity. https://t.co/suacsPhDh1
#45 shows off one side of Archetypes that I particularly love: their minimalism. It's structure and its use of the palette are both quite muted. https://t.co/U6Kd9PFchy

I've long wanted to make a triptych of Archetypes (@kgolid) that showcases how Archetypes range from minimal and order towards chaos and complexity. I've put together a trio in my favorite palette (Paddle) that I'd like to share. ü§ó https://t.co/qTpoIb4MhY
